definitions: surprise or attack someone from a direction they cannot see or did not expect
examples: The news about the company closure completely blindsided all employees
The football player was blindsided by a tackle from behind

definitions: shut and open eyes quickly as a natural reflex or deliberately
turn on and off repeatedly like a light or signal
examples: She had to blink several times in the bright sunlight
Don't blink or you'll miss the shooting star
The computer cursor blinks when you're typing a document
Warning lights blinked red throughout the emergency evacuation

definitions: cause or develop a raised bubble on skin from heat friction or burning
attack someone with extremely harsh criticism or intense verbal assault
examples: These new shoes will blister my feet if I walk too far
The hot sun blistered the paint on the old wooden fence
The coach blistered the team for their poor performance yesterday
Critics blistered the movie with scathing reviews

definitions: launch a sudden intense military attack or aggressive campaign against a target
work through something very quickly with intense effort and energy
examples: The team plans to blitz the quarterback on every third down
The company will blitz the market with advertising next month
We need to blitz through these reports before the deadline
She decided to blitz clean the house before guests arrived

definitions: seal off a place to prevent goods or people from entering or leaving
examples: Naval forces blockaded the harbor to stop weapon shipments
Protesters blockaded the building entrance for three hours

definitions: produce flowers or be in flower as plants do in season
grow develop or come to a healthy promising state
examples: The cherry trees bloom beautifully every spring in the park
Most roses bloom from late spring through early fall
Her artistic talent bloomed after she started taking classes
The small business bloomed into a successful corporation

definitions: produce or yield flowers especially on fruit trees in springtime
develop in a healthy or promising way reaching full potential
examples: Apple trees blossom with white flowers before producing fruit
The plum trees blossomed early this year due to warm weather
She blossomed into a confident public speaker over time
Their friendship blossomed after working together on the project

definitions: dry or soak up liquid by pressing absorbent material against it
make a spot or stain especially with ink or liquid
examples: Use a tissue to blot the spilled coffee from the table
She carefully blotted her lipstick with a napkin
Be careful not to blot the paper with wet ink
Tears blotted the handwritten letter making words unreadable

definitions: cover or mark something with large irregular spots or patches of color
examples: Crying had blotched her face with red patches
The disease blotched the tree leaves with brown spots

definitions: cry noisily and uncontrollably while making sobbing sounds
examples: The child blubbered after falling off the bicycle
She blubbered through the entire sad movie scene

definitions: make a detailed plan or technical drawing for something to be built
examples: The architect blueprinted the new office building design carefully
They blueprinted every step of the business expansion plan

definitions: try to deceive someone by pretending to have strength knowledge or confidence
examples: He tried to bluff his way through the job interview
Don't let them bluff you into accepting a bad deal

definitions: make a stupid or careless mistake due to lack of thought
move in a clumsy unsteady way bumping into things
examples: The company blundered by ignoring customer feedback for years
He blundered badly when he forgot the client's name
She blundered through the dark room looking for the light switch
The drunk man blundered into several tables leaving the bar

definitions: make something less sharp by dulling its edge or point
say something in a very direct way without trying to be polite
examples: Using the knife on concrete will blunt the blade quickly
Years of use had blunted the scissors
Let me blunt with you about your performance issues
She tends to blunt her criticism with humor

definitions: make or become unclear or less distinct in outline or detail
move so fast that clear visual details cannot be seen
examples: Tears blurred her vision as she read the letter
The rain blurred the view through the car windshield
The race car blurred past the spectators at incredible speed
Days blurred together during the long hospital stay

definitions: develop a pink or red color in the face from embarrassment shame or modesty
examples: She couldn't help but blush when he complimented her
He blushed deeply when caught telling a lie

definitions: talk with excessive pride about one's achievements possessions or abilities
examples: He constantly boasts about his expensive car collection
Don't boast about your grades in front of struggling students

definitions: move quickly up and down or back and forth repeatedly
cut hair in a short style that hangs straight around the head
examples: The fishing float bobbed gently on the water surface
She bobbed her head to the rhythm of the music
She decided to bob her long hair for summer
The stylist bobbed her hair in a classic 1920s style

definitions: move with an unsteady rocking or bouncing motion
handle something clumsily almost dropping or losing control of it
examples: The boat bobbled on the choppy waves
Her head bobbled as she fought to stay awake
The quarterback bobbled the snap but recovered quickly
She bobbled the hot coffee cup and spilled some

definitions: ride or race in a sled designed for speed on an ice track
examples: The team will bobsled in the Winter Olympics next year
She learned to bobsled at the training facility in Calgary

definitions: be a sign or warning of a future event usually something bad
examples: Dark clouds bode poorly for our beach picnic plans
These early signs don't bode well for the economy

definitions: sink or cause to sink into soft wet muddy ground
slow down or become stuck preventing normal progress or movement
examples: The heavy truck bogged in the muddy field
Don't walk there or you'll bog in the swamp
The meeting bogged down in endless technical discussions
Don't let minor details bog down the main project

definitions: score one stroke over par on a golf hole in a round
examples: He bogeyed the difficult fifth hole after hitting into sand
She rarely bogeys when playing her home course

definitions: print or write text in thick heavy type to make it stand out
examples: Please boldface all the important dates in the document
The editor boldfaced key terms throughout the textbook

definitions: support strengthen or reinforce something to make it more effective or substantial
examples: Additional evidence will bolster your argument in court
The company hired consultants to bolster their marketing strategy

definitions: run away suddenly and quickly often from fear or panic
fasten or secure something using a metal bolt or similar device
examples: The horse bolted when it heard the loud thunder
She bolted from the room when she saw the spider
Make sure to bolt the door before going to bed
The mechanic bolted the new parts securely in place

definitions: attack continuously with bombs shells or other missiles or with questions information
examples: Enemy forces bombarded the city for three days straight
Reporters bombarded the politician with difficult questions

definitions: make a deep resonant sound like a large bell or gong
examples: The church bell bonged twelve times at midnight
The grandfather clock bongs every hour on the hour

definitions: shout to show disapproval or contempt typically at a performance or speaker
examples: The crowd booed when the referee made a bad call
Angry fans booed the team off the field

definitions: dance energetically to rock or pop music in an informal way
examples: Everyone started to boogie when the DJ played classic disco
Let's boogie on the dance floor until midnight

definitions: return to harm or affect the originator of an action or plan
examples: His dishonest tactics boomeranged and ruined his reputation
The negative campaign boomeranged against the political party

definitions: make distribute or sell goods illegally especially alcohol or recordings
examples: People used to bootleg alcohol during Prohibition era
Some fans bootleg concert recordings despite copyright laws

definitions: improve or develop something using only existing resources and one's own efforts
examples: She bootstrapped her business from a small home office
The startup bootstrapped for two years before seeking investors

definitions: drink alcohol especially in large quantities or habitually
examples: He tends to booze heavily at weekend parties
Don't booze and drive after the celebration tonight

definitions: hit or strike someone or something lightly and quickly
dance to jazz or pop music in a casual bouncy way
examples: She playfully bopped him on the head with a pillow
The cat bopped the toy mouse with its paw
They love to bop to old jazz records on weekends
Everyone was bopping to the live band's music

definitions: make a hole in something using a drill or similar tool
make someone feel weary and uninterested by being dull or tedious
examples: They need to bore through the wall to install pipes
The carpenter bored holes for the cabinet handles
Long speeches tend to bore most audience members quickly
Don't bore everyone with your vacation photos

definitions: cause congestion or blockage that slows down progress flow or production
examples: Construction work bottlenecked traffic during morning rush hour
Outdated equipment bottlenecks the entire manufacturing process

definitions: move forward with leaping jumps or springs
form the boundary or limit of something restricting its scope
examples: The deer bounded gracefully across the meadow
The excited dog bounded up the stairs
Mountains bound the valley on three sides
Legal contracts bound what the company could do

definitions: refuse to buy use or participate in something as a protest or punishment
examples: Consumers boycotted the company over its labor practices
Students voted to boycott the cafeteria until prices dropped

definitions: prepare oneself for something difficult or unpleasant that is coming
strengthen or support something with a rigid structure or brackets
examples: Passengers should brace for turbulence during the storm
She braced herself before hearing the test results
They need to brace the old fence before winter storms
The dentist braced her teeth to correct alignment

definitions: place people or things in groups with similar characteristics
support or attach something using angled metal or wooden supports
examples: The tax code brackets income into different rate categories
Scientists bracket these species based on genetic similarities
We need to bracket these shelves to the wall securely
The contractor bracketed the awning to provide extra support

definitions: say something in a boastful manner to impress others with achievements
examples: He always brags about his high test scores to classmates
Stop bragging about your new car all the time

definitions: interweave three or more strands of hair fabric or other flexible material
examples: She learned to braid her daughter's hair in different styles
They braid rope from natural fibers at the craft shop

definitions: write or print using the raised dot system for blind people to read
examples: The library brailles books for visually impaired readers
She learned to braille important documents for her students

definitions: produce ideas or solve problems by spontaneous group discussion and creative thinking
examples: Let's brainstorm solutions to increase customer satisfaction
The team will brainstorm marketing ideas this afternoon

definitions: make someone adopt radically different beliefs by using systematic pressure and manipulation
examples: The cult tried to brainwash new members with constant propaganda
Some worry that social media can brainwash young people

definitions: slow down or stop a moving vehicle by using the brake system
examples: You need to brake gently on icy roads to avoid skidding
The driver had to brake suddenly when a deer appeared

definitions: shout to express approval especially after a performance
examples: The audience bravoed enthusiastically after the opera performance
Critics bravoed the young violinist's debut concert

definitions: fight or quarrel in a rough noisy way especially in public places
examples: Several fans began to brawl after the soccer match
The brothers would often brawl over trivial matters

definitions: make the loud harsh cry of a donkey or similar sound
examples: The donkey brayed loudly when it saw its food coming
He brayed with laughter at the comedian's jokes
